name: There’s no doubt that this initiative, if truly about reducing costs and increasing quality / coverage, has the potential to improve the lives of those with employer-provided healthcare. But, what about those that have to buy on their own?

content.html: There’s no doubt that this initiative, if truly about reducing costs and increasing quality / coverage, has the potential to improve the lives of those with employer-provided healthcare. But, what about those that have to buy on their own?
content.value: There’s no doubt that this initiative, if truly about reducing costs and increasing quality / coverage, has the potential to improve the lives of those with employer-provided healthcare. But, what about those that have to buy on their own?

summary: @cleverdevil I'll argue if the US healthcare system goes away from the profit-motivated middleman, then individual buyers benefit, too.

content.html: @cleverdevil I'll argue if the US healthcare system goes away from the profit-motivated middleman, then individual buyers benefit, too.
content.value: @cleverdevil I'll argue if the US healthcare system goes away from the profit-motivated middleman, then individual buyers benefit, too.

summary: @kitt I think I agree with you. That said, I believe healthcare is a human right, and while lower premiums for individual buyers is helpful, it still doesn’t accommodate extremely low income people.

content.html: @kitt I think I agree with you. That said, I believe healthcare is a human right, and while lower premiums for individual buyers is helpful, it still doesn’t accommodate extremely low income people.
content.value: @kitt I think I agree with you. That said, I believe healthcare is a human right, and while lower premiums for individual buyers is helpful, it still doesn’t accommodate extremely low income people.

summary: @cleverdevil agreed. Having experienced universal healthcare, even as an outsider, it is damn wonderful.
